row.entry: Medical Director, Homeless Programs Company VA Central Office (VACO) 1601 E. Fourth Plain Blvd. Vancouver, WA 98661
Director, Education-Dissemination, National Center on Homelessness, Veteran Health Administration (VHA)

chapter.title: External Data Definitions
chapter.para: No externalData expression definitions and no trigger definitions are present.

chapter.title: Screening
chapter.para: All Veterans should be screened for homelessness (and near-future risk) annually, unless the Veteran is a long-term resident of a nursing home/long-term care facility

row.entry: Condition:elm:Contains (elm:Property("Homeless screen performed" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses)) elm:Literal())
Ask Patient: In the past 2 months, have you been living in stable housing? By that, we mean housing that is affordable, permanent, safe, decent, and livable.
No, not living in stable housing
Yes, confident in continuing to live in stable housing
No, not confident in continuing to live in stable housing
Where have you lived for MOST of the past 2 months?
Short-term institution, such as hospital, rehab center, drug treatment center
Anywhere outside, such as street, vehicle, abandoned building
Ask Patient: Would you like to be referred to talk more about your housing situation?

Condition:elm:Or (elm:Contains( elm:Property("stableHousing" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses)) elm:Literal()) elm:Contains( elm:Property("confidentLivingInStableHousing" from: elm:ParameterRef(Responses)) elm:Literal()))
Patient agrees to referral for homelessness services or assistance
Patient declines referral at this time; given information for future reference
Ask Patient: What is the best way to reach you?
Already receiving homelessness services or assistance
Long-term resident of nursing home/long-term care facility
All Veterans should be screened for food insecurity unless the Veteran is a resident of a nursing home/long-term care facility
Ask Patient “In the past 3 months, did you ever run out of food and you were not able to access more food or have the money to buy more food?
Yes, food shortage and no money to buy food or access to food
Ask patient “Are you confident that you will continue to have enough food or money to buy food for at least the next 3 months?
Yes, confident in continued access to food
No, not confident in continued access to food
Ask Patient: Would you like to be referred to talk more about your food shortage situation?
Patient agrees to referral to social services
Patient agrees to referral to nutrition and food services
Patient declines referral at this time; given information for future reference
Reasons for not performing Food Insecurity Screen
Already receiving services or assistance to address known food insecurity issue
Resident of nursing home/long-term care facility

entry.link: 22c9bf08-1d5c-4da9-a0af-0ae4940d240f |Veterans Affairs Homeless Veterans Assistance Center consultation and report (procedure)

row.entry: Veteran has been identified as being currently homeless or homeless within the past 2 months
Veteran has been identified as being at risk of homelessness within the next 60 days
Describe in detail the Veteran’s current living situation
Order consult for social work or for nutrition and food services

entry.link: c86bf351-ec7e-4310-ae35-5cfc41d3f9fe |Nutrition and food services consultation and report (procedure)

row.entry: Veteran has been identified as having a current food shortage or a food shortage within the past 3 months
Veteran has been identified as being at risk of a food shortage within the next 90 days
Describe in detail the Veteran’s current food situation

Display Text
If a code is used multiple times in the KNART, only the display text of the first instance is shown.

References
Count of the number of times the given code system and code pair is used in the KNART.
22c9bf08-1d5c-4da9-a0af-0ae4940d240f |Veterans Affairs Homeless Veterans Assistance Center consultation and report (procedure)
c86bf351-ec7e-4310-ae35-5cfc41d3f9fe |Nutrition and food services consultation and report (procedure)

A group of related alternative actions is a sentence group if the item referenced by the action is the same in all the actions, and each action simply constitutes a different variation on how to specify the details for that item. For example, two actions that could be in a SentenceGroup are "aspirin, 500 mg, 2 times per day" and "aspirin, 300 mg, 3 times per day". In both cases, aspirin is the item referenced by the action, and the two actions represent two different options for how aspirin might be ordered for the patient. Note that a SentenceGroup would almost always have an associated selection behavior of "AtMostOne", unless it's a required action, in which case, it would be "ExactlyOne".
A group with this behavior logically groups its sub-elements, and may be shown as a visual group to the end user, but it is not required to do so.
Any group marked with this behavior should be displayed as a visual group to the end user.
Any number of the items in the group may be chosen, from zero to all.
All the items in the group must be selected as a single unit.
All the items in the group are meant to be chosen as a single unit: either all must be selected by the end user, or none may be selected.
The end user must choose one and only one of the selectable items in the group. The user may not choose none of the items in the group.
The end user may choose zero or at most one of the items in the group.
The end user must choose a minimum of one, and as many additional as desired.
An action with this behavior must be included in the actions processed by the end user; the end user may not choose not to include this action.
An action with this behavior may be included in the set of actions processed by the end user.
An action with this behavior must be included in the set of actions processed by the end user, unless the end user provides documentation as to why the action was not included.

An action with this behavior is one of the most frequent actions that is, or should be, included by an end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the action to the end user should consider "pre-checking" such an action as a convenience for the user.

An action with this behavior is one of the less frequent actions included by the end user, for the particular context in which the action occurs. The system displaying the actions to the end user would typically not "pre-check" such an action.
An action with this behavior may only be completed once.
An action with this behavior may be repeated multiple times.
This item, in a list entry, allows the user to enter a fill in value that is not present in the set of presented choices.
For a particular action or action group, specifies whether the elements are read only.

Chhabra 2018 Chhabra M, Cusack C, Dichter M, Montgomery AE, True G. Screening for homelessness: VA provider reflections on addressing a social determinant of health. Poster presented at: Academy Health Annual Research Meeting 2017 June 25-27, 2017 Accessed January 30, 2018 (link)

Fargo 2017 Fargo JD, Montgomery AE, Byrne T, Brignone E, Cusack M, Gundlapalli AV. Needles in a haystack: screening and healthcare system evidence for homelessness. Stud Health Technol Inform. 2017;235:574-578 (link)

Montgomery 2014 Montgomery AE, Fargo JD, Kane V, Culhane DP. Development and validation of an instrument to assess imminent risk of homelessness among veterans. Public Health Rep. 2014;129(5):428-436 (link)
OToole 2017 O'Toole TP, Roberts CB, Johnson EE. Screening for Food Insecurity in Six Veterans Administration Clinics for the Homeless, June-December 2015. Prev Chronic Dis. 2017;14:E04 (link)
